This course introduces you to contemporary design as an integrated practice, which involves creative understanding and engagement with design elements, principles, contexts, experimentation and research. The course covers 2, 3 and 4 dimensional aspects, processes and precedents of design. There is a practical focus on drawing, prototyping and making to represent a range of design concepts.

contentlets.description: This course introduces you to contemporary design as an integrated practice, which involves creative understanding and engagement with design elements, principles, contexts, experimentation and research. The course covers 2, 3 and 4 dimensional aspects, processes and precedents of design. There is a practical focus on drawing, prototyping and making to represent a range of design concepts.
contentlets.title: Design Studio 1 - Design Narratives

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1101 - Design Studio 2 - Design Communication","description":"

Design Studio 2 builds on the fundamental principles and processes of design as learnt in Design Studio 1. You will be introduced to a range of methods, purposes and application of design communication. You will develop skills in engagement, collaboration and presentation to a range of stakeholders and contexts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c1a02753db213c50be4672f5f39619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Contemporary design is a practice that integrates theory, context and studio practice. This project allows you to reflect on your entire first year of study and provides you with opportunities to draw connections between all of your courses, and to create further self-guided work to inform your developing practice. You will demonstrate this through the curated narrative of your portfolio which should now be more complex and outward facing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d9a02753db213c50be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51a02753db213c50be4672f5f39619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Context and Communication","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The emphasis of the project is on communicating design research and outcomes for a range of different contexts and stakeholders, and taking account of design considerations. You will collaborate on a series of groups activities which you will then develop into an individual communication project. At a practical level you will utilise effective visual, written and verbal communication in both digital and analogue formats to present your project.

You will be individually assessed on your own work, as well as your contribution to the group processes and outcomes, and your engagement with your peers.

You will need to document all of your work in a process journal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c9a02753db213c50be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d1a02753db213c50be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d5a02753db213c50be4672f5f39619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Communication and Considerations","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

There are a range of skills and knowledge which are common to all design disciplines.

The purpose of this assessment it to evaluate your understanding of some of the key fundamentals needed when starting out as a design student. These include:

  • Glossary of terms
  • Design considerations
  • Types of communication

contentlets.description: Design Studio 2 builds on the fundamental principles and processes of design as learnt in Design Studio 1. You will be introduced to a range of methods, purposes and application of design communication. You will develop skills in engagement, collaboration and presentation to a range of stakeholders and contexts.
contentlets.title: Design Studio 2 - Design Communication

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1110 - 3D Visualisation 1: 3D Virtual Objects","description":"

This foundation studio course will develop your understanding of creative 3D computer visualisation. It will provide you with live, hands-on experience of the key technologies and creative thinking that is required when designing 3D virtual objects. You will be introduced to the historical and contemporary developments in 3D Visualisation and Computer Generated Imagery (CGI). Practical studio workshops will explore 3D CGI workflow for a variety of digital media, 3D modelling techniques, the application of foundational art and design theoretical thinking, and the previsualisation and planning of a virtual object. The course will primarily focus on constructing virtual objects for pre-rendering screen-based output. At the end of the course you will have planned and created a 3D virtual object through the application of a series of techniques and methods, giving you an introductory experience of the field of computer modelling.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3ec0e393db213c50be4672f5f3961941","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Object 3D Visualisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment will guide students to the realisation of their 3D virtual model. Students will draw on the background research they have accumulated and take into consideration all tests they have carried out during the previsualisation phase. Students will demonstrate their work in progress by providing screen shots of their 3D process to Moodle Galleries. 

The final model will be fully resolved: UV mapped, textured and rendered. Students must individually submit a series of four static rendered digital images (1920x1080 pixel size) of their model, and a zipped folder of their Maya project.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"32c0e393db213c50be4672f5f3961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Previsualisation: Narrative and data gathering","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to become familiar with the process of researching and previsualising 3D CGI objects. Students will be required to source some form of found or created 3D object and build a narrative around their chosen object. How the students interpret and construct the visual aesthetic should be informed by narrative and a basic level of theoretical thinking.

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bec0e393db213c50be4672f5f3961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Previsualisation: Narrative and Data Gathering","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The intention of this project is to explore design themes and how to begin to apply them to asset design. As designers, we draw from past design trends, our own personal experiences and what we observe every day in the world. The ability to ‘see’ the detail and extraordinary that exists around us in what may appear mundane and ordinary is critical as a designer, as is the ability to identify and understand the historical context behind an observed design. We must learn to analyse artefacts and see beyond the superficial to distil out themes, responding to our experiences through our design work. Using your research and previsualisation skills, you are asked to reimagine an everyday object through the lens of a particular design movement examined in class and communicate your research process.

Electronic submission via Moodle Assignment submission link. One A3 PDF research board (maximum file size 200MB).

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f6c0e393db213c50be4672f5f3961946","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES1110.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1120 - Object 1: Objects and the Hand","description":"

This course introduces you to object design by emphasising thinking-through-making as a framework to creatively explore and generate ideas. Thinking-through-making describes an iterative design process that involves critical evaluation of making processes. In the course you will develop an understanding of how to work with, research and experience different materials to produce a portfolio of design objects. You will also develop knowledge of contemporary craft in the field of design practice. A unique feature of this course is the acquisition of fundamental design and making skills that can be applied to specific design contexts including domestic and wearable objects.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f1c7a497db31b410595850d8f49619c6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Analysis & Process Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment introduces you to the field of contemporary craft by analysing two craft objects, and by documenting material and technical knowledge of processes learned in ceramics and jewellery. This research document is intended to contribute towards the development of your studio investigations for Assessment Task 2 by providing design inspiration and documentation of skills learned for referencing during the making process.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"31c7a497db31b410595850d8f49619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39c7a497db31b410595850d8f49619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3dc7a497db31b410595850d8f49619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02c7a497db31b410595850d8f49619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Studio Investigations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment introduces you to contemporary craft methods in design practice by emphasising thinking-through-making as a research framework to creatively explore and generate ideas in three-dimensional form. Thinking-through-making describes an iterative design process that involves critical evaluation and reflection of making practices. Responding to a project theme, you will apply knowledge learned throughout the course about materials and processes to produce a series of hand-crafted objects.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1130 - Experience 1: Spaces and Senses","description":"

In this course, you will explore the way people experience and interact with space, connecting this with ideas of the body, materiality, culture and spectacle. You will learn to design spatial, time-based and atmospheric conditions that affect engagement with the built world.


The course offers multi-dimensional exploration of spatial experience that incorporates ideas from philosophy, architecture and neuroscience to better understand, anticipate and design for human behaviour. Through the design of installations you are invited to experiment, examine, measure and critically interpret space, time and narratives with an emphasis on the investigation of social, cultural, ethical and environmental sustainability issues and practices. You will work with diverse design and presentation methods to develop skills and techniques that communicate your ideas.


Advanced study in this discipline can lead to careers in exhibition and event design as well as pathways centred on your own inquiry-led design practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a5212717db213c50be4672f5f39619ac","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Esquisses of Space and Experience","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

A collection of sketch responses using devices such as the diagram, the model and the drawing to explore form, scale, space, time and the lived body.

These exercises are intended to help you get into the practice of spatial and experiential development and consider qualities, properties and relationships between the intimate scale of the senses and the larger scale of the built environment with which the body engages.

Feedback is to be provided formally in the form of written response and grading.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"25212717db213c50be4672f5f39619b1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"An Experiential Installation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

You are asked to build on the ideas explored and research presented in the initial experimentation period of the course. The project asks for a response to a brief for an installation focusing on the choreography of the senses and the space to produce an immersive experience. You are encouraged to experiment with methods of recording and representing the intent for your designed environment as well as organising this for presentation. Research and articulation of issues surrounding sustainability and ephemerality/impermanence is to be incorporated into your submission.

In-progress advice will be delivered informally during tutorials with formal feedback provided in the form of written response and grading following final submission of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d212717db213c50be4672f5f39619af","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES1130.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.description:
In this course, you will explore the way people experience and interact with space, connecting this with ideas of the body, materiality, culture and spectacle. You will learn to design spatial, time-based and atmospheric conditions that affect engagement with the built world.

The course offers multi-dimensional exploration of spatial experience that incorporates ideas from philosophy, architecture and neuroscience to better understand, anticipate and design for human behaviour. Through the design of installations you are invited to experiment, examine, measure and critically interpret space, time and narratives with an emphasis on the investigation of social, cultural, ethical and environmental sustainability issues and practices. You will work with diverse design and presentation methods to develop skills and techniques that communicate your ideas.

Advanced study in this discipline can lead to careers in exhibition and event design as well as pathways centred on your own inquiry-led design practice.
contentlets.title: Experience 1: Spaces and Senses

is based. Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1140 - Graphics 1: Image and Type","description":"

This course offers you an introductory opportunity to develop critical skills in the creation of graphic images through photography and various types of illustration. You will then begin to understand how to manipulate typography within formal grids and structures, and as an expressive medium. Graphic design is built on a sound understanding of the relationship between image and type.


Whether you are intending to work either commercially or experimentally within the visual communications industry, or as a design entrepreneur working in another context, this course will provide you with fundamental graphic design skills. Through application to your individual practice, you will understand the importance of research, an iterative design process, ethical considerations, as well as the personal and presentation skills required to communicate a concept.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5f41e357db213c50be4672f5f3961920","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Image Fundamentals","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Through a program of ongoing activities, students will explore a range of illustrative and photographic techniques to generate image solutions suitable for reproduction. The focus will be on experimentation, image generation and iteration which will be evidenced in an image portfolio and visual journal.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback on a final image portfolio, visual journal, and course reflection will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f41e357db213c50be4672f5f3961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Type Fundamentals","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will develop an understanding of the fundamentals of typography and begin to apply these principles in the layout of text and image. The emphasis will be on introducing a more formal and iterative graphic design process resulting in a project-based outcome. Students will create a prototype or mockup, and present this in the final class of the semester.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on a final publication, in-class presentation, visual journal, and course reflection will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9741e357db213c50be4672f5f3961925","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES1140.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: domain design,graphic design,typography,illustration,photography,design fundamentals,narrative,visual communication,mark making
contentlets.description:
This course offers you an introductory opportunity to develop critical skills in the creation of graphic images through photography and various types of illustration. You will then begin to understand how to manipulate typography within formal grids and structures, and as an expressive medium. Graphic design is built on a sound understanding of the relationship between image and type.

Whether you are intending to work either commercially or experimentally within the visual communications industry, or as a design entrepreneur working in another context, this course will provide you with fundamental graphic design skills. Through application to your individual practice, you will understand the importance of research, an iterative design process, ethical considerations, as well as the personal and presentation skills required to communicate a concept.
contentlets.title: Graphics 1: Image and Type

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1150 - Interaction 1: Principles and Practices","description":"

Interaction design focuses upon the creation of cohesive user experiences, typically but not exclusively associated with digital systems, for products, websites, environments and services. It involves the study of objects and their affordances, and how people interact with the world, and takes into account diverse practices to study and prototype new interactive experiences. This is a foundation level course which will provide you with an introduction to the field within the traditional sphere of the screen in web and mobile contexts, and covers the basic foundations for working as an interaction design professional in the relevant industries. The design of graphical user interfaces (GUIs) will be explored through professional conceptual frameworks and design processes. Ideation, wireframes, prototypes and walkthroughs will be used to develop a workflow for designing and testing successful GUIs. Throughout the course, you will be presented with the key concepts that underpin interaction design through the exploration of major trends that are transforming the industry and changing modern life. This course will give you the building blocks to become proficient in the application of interaction design concepts through hands-on experience at prototyping and building interactive systems.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3c716397db213c50be4672f5f39619af","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Graphical user interface concept development, critical discussion board and design","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The core purpose of this task is to conduct a critical study of Graphical User Interface (GUI) designs and how they interact in the creation of a user experience. This will take into account factors such as interaction, animation, visibility, layout, typography, and so on. In this activity, you should recognise that many GUIs need to selectively balance the information available to the user, which is something that is done in close integration with the entire experience design of the product. For example, consider how stark minimal designs such as AirBnB or Tinder, which hide away choices in favour of a more direct visual experience, changed the way we experience such services.

Work will be presented in a poster presentation which frames students’ design research and presents their prototype designs.

Additional research notes and materials will be presented in weekly class activities.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4716397db213c50be4672f5f39619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Graphical application, design, prototype and test","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment Description and feedback process: In this final project students will respond to a design brief to develop their own GUI and sonic interaction design concepts for screen/mouse/keyboard, touch screen or other USB or Bluetooth input device. They will implement a prototype and design and conduct user-tests using other members of the class. A detailed brief will be provided via Moodle.

The assignment has the following steps:

  1. Review existing use cases relating to the brief. Look at different designs and different ways to order or filter the data. Study these in use and see how they influence behaviour - use yourself or friends as case studies, through observation or interviews.

  2. Brainstorm* to come up with three or more radically different ideas about how you might design an experience. Remember to apply brainstorming principles properly; go for wild and unobvious ideas and withhold judgement.

  3. Select one of the ideas and dive deeper into it in a more in-depth scoping study. You can revise the idea as you go. Develop designs, user scenarios and sketches that will enable you to better walk through design possibilities, revising the concept as you go. (Note this should be feeding back into the core concepts - you will derive new design principles and imposed constraints, such as Twitter’s famous 140 character constraint).

  4. Build more in-depth prototypes of your designs and devise user studies that you can run on your classmates, allowing further reflection on your designs.

  5. Refine and pitch a final design concept. In your final presentation, you should tell the whole story: your three-or-more initial concepts and your refinement.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1160 - Textiles 1: Concepts and Context","description":"

This course will introduce you to the narrative aspect of textiles, and their story telling ability via patterns, materials and construction. It will familiarise you with the qualities and characteristics of textiles, as well as the key processes for designing and creating them through the integration of hand and digital design methods. You will consider social, cultural, environmental and sustainable themes that will become influential to your textile practice. Throughout the course you will employ research methodologies appropriate to the textile design industry and investigate selected textile theorists and writers to critically evaluate, document and reflect. You will investigate the local culture of textile practitioners to inspire and develop unique surface designs. In this course, you are encouraged to play, experiment and learn from failure and take creative risks in the development of cohesive conceptually-based textiles.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ca91ef97db213c50be4672f5f39619e9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Fabric to Form – Designing Textile Objects","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

From 2D to 3D – using your repeat designs from Assessment 1, design an object that expands on your original design narrative and demonstrates the functional use of the textile. 

- Create an object that expands on your original design narrative and demonstrates the functional use of the textile. 
- Create a presentation book that illustrates your 3D design (using the techniques learnt in class) and includes a concept statement. 
- Document your experimentation and process; analysis and design development and annotate your technical analysis in your design journal. 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0691ef97db213c50be4672f5f39619ee","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Fibre to Fabric – Designing Textile Narratives","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Your task is to design a collection of three contemporary two-dimentional surface-patterns that communicate a cohesive textile design narrative based on original creative research and exploration of material properties, referencing a textile tradition. 

Part A. Identify a local textile designer and their location and lines of investigation that enable you to contextualise their conceptual and methodological processes in textile materials.

Part B. Design two repeat prints inspired by their stories, concepts, methods, place or practices to create an original ‘design narrative’ that demonstrates your ability to work with processes suitable for screen print and heat press applications utilising digital and hand mark-making for textile design.

Through hands-on exploration of fibre types, yarn structures and natural dye processes with the class, individually create an original piece of woven cloth as a sampler. Select a section of the sampler to scan digitally and experiment with scale and repetition to create a third repeat print to complement your ‘design narrative’.

contentlets.keywords: domain design,textiles design,fashion design,costume design,wearables,interior design,architectural application,public art,installation,object design,surface design,materials,smart textiles,fibre,fibre art,textile art,screen printing,print
contentlets.description: This course will introduce you to the narrative aspect of textiles, and their story telling ability via patterns, materials and construction. It will familiarise you with the qualities and characteristics of textiles, as well as the key processes for designing and creating them through the integration of hand and digital design methods. You will consider social, cultural, environmental and sustainable themes that will become influential to your textile practice. Throughout the course you will employ research methodologies appropriate to the textile design industry and investigate selected textile theorists and writers to critically evaluate, document and reflect. You will investigate the local culture of textile practitioners to inspire and develop unique surface designs. In this course, you are encouraged to play, experiment and learn from failure and take creative risks in the development of cohesive conceptually-based textiles.
contentlets.title: Textiles 1: Concepts and Context

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1200 - Design History and Theory 1","description":"

This course will provide you with an overview of the historical context of design and introduce you to the core principles and theories that underpin design history. At the conclusion of this course, you will understand the relevance and purpose of the study of history to the practice of design in relation to your own developing design practice. Design is ubiquitous and infiltrates everyday life via its many forms, including design objects, environments, processes and systems. But, how did we get here? Practicing designers need to understand that design does not operate in a closed-loop, rather that it is contingent on the wider context of the world we live in and, importantly, it’s historical precedence.


This course introduces you to the ways in which design artefacts are shaped by, and understood within, ranging historical frames and narratives. Through a series of tasks, you will explore the various trajectories of design history theory and, through applied academic research skills, demonstrate the contingency of historical understanding and knowledge in relation to design practice.


You will interpret design objects, environments, processes and systems through visual analysis and employ your new skills to demonstrate your understanding of design history theory in relation to contemporary design practice. Your analysis will be supported through learning practical academic research skills, including the effective sourcing, attribution and critical analysis of research material. You will demonstrate oral, written and visual communication skills throughout each of these tasks.


  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"efb1afd7db213c50be4672f5f3961979","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Constructs: Interpreting Design Objects","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

For the final task, you will synthesis the knowledge and skills that you have acquired throughout the course to produce a collaborative design object catalogue. In groups, you will be allocated a contemporary design which you will research, contextualise, and then interpret through individual theoretical lenses.

This tasks requires you and your group members to discuss and debate the significance of your design from a range of perspectives. The aim of the task is not to present a coherent understanding, rather it is to demonstrate that the design history is both mutable and malleable and through careful examination, we can understand design objects, environments, processes and systems through a range of contexts.

To successfully complete this task, you will need to undertake this assessment in three stages. First, you will conduct a semiotic and formal analysis of your allocated design, and supplement this with scholarly research. You will then collaborate with your group to present your findings in the form of a 10 minute in-class debate. Finally, you will synthesize your analysis, research and group discussions into a designed catalogue that presents your design through each group members individual theoretical lens.

Your catalogue can take any aesthetic form, and should include at least two pages of content from each group member, with a maximum word-count of 500 words per group member. As a group you should consider what narrative and aesthetic threads you can employ to produce a cohesive final catalogue.    

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e7b1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7b1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"efb1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"efb1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3bb1afd7db213c50be4672f5f3961987","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Deconstructed Design Objects","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

In this task, you will deconstruct a design object using formal and semiotic visual analysis methods. Using these methods, lecture content and supported by further scholarly research, you will identify relevant contexts and design history narratives that influence how this object is perceived.

You will present your analysis and research in the form of a 1200—1500-word written submission, to be submitted in week 7. Your report should include at least three supporting images, sourced from an appropriate scholarly source and referenced in-text. Your submission must also include a reference list, formatted using the correct referencing conventions.

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e7b1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7b1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"efb1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"efb1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63b1afd7db213c50be4672f5f396197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Desire Lines: Non-linear Academic Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This task is comprised of two-parts: In the first part, to be submitted in week 3, you will identify, source/collect and write a scholarly reference using correct referencing conventions. In the second part, to be submitted in week 4, you will expand your research to produce a visual literature map that illustrates your research journey.

To do this task, you will select a topic area from the first three weeks of Design History Theory that you are curious to know more about. Using this topic as a starting point you should conduct scholarly research using the resources available to you through in lectures and tutorials, the UNSW Library and online modules.

For part 1 you should identify one source of interest from your research and write down the scholarly reference using correct referencing conventions. You should also explain in 2 – 3 sentences why this source is interesting and relevant to your selected topic area. Your reference and supporting reflections should be submitted as a digital .pdf to the Moodle dropbox in week 3.

For part 2 you will repeat this process and identify, source/collect and correctly write references for at least 2 books, 2 journal articles and 2 online sources related to this topic. You will present these sources in the form a visual literature map that demonstrates your understanding of non-linear research. It should provide evidence of your journey and the links between your scholarly sources in the form of photographs, illustrations, diagrams, keywords and written reflections. Your map will be comprised of a single A4 page that includes at least 6 scholarly references, and can include up to 10 scholarly references in total. Your map can take any aesthetic form, but should be submitted as a digital .pdf to the dropbox.

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1201 - Design History and Theory 2","description":"

In this course, you will investigate the central question, “what is design?” and consider key theories that will explore this question from a number of different historical and contemporary perspectives. Using the knowledge and research and analysis skills developed in the introductory Design History and Theory course, you will further investigate these theories in relation to key contexts in design such as globalisation, sustainability, ethics and innovation. Through a series of lectures and tutorials, you will develop and implement the tools required to critically reflect upon and communicate your practice in nuanced and effective ways. At the conclusion of this course, you will understand the relevance and purpose of design theory to your own design practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9de12f1bdb213c50be4672f5f39619c2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Project Part 2: Academic Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Using the annotated bibliography you prepared in Part 1 of your research project, you will devise a research question on the subject of design. This research question will be discussed with and approved by your tutor. In investigating your research question, you will write an academic essay of 2000 words on your findings. In this essay, you will apply the knowledge and skills in analysis developed throughout the course to explore design theory in relation to design case studies. You will reference material covered in the lectures and tutorials and conduct independent research for your essay. There will be an opportunity to receive one-on-one feedback on your essay from your tutor before the submission date. You will also have access to a variety of resources to support you in writing an academic essay.

Feedback will be delivered electronically 2 weeks after the submission date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d1e12f1bdb213c50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d1e12f1bdb213c50be4672f5f39619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9e12f1bdb213c50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d9e12f1bdb213c50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91e12f1bdb213c50be4672f5f39619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Project Part 1: Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This task is Part 1 of a two part research project. You will compile an annotated bibliography of quality research sources that discuss or use design theory. They must be relevant to two of the design contexts studied, one of which you will select from the first half of the course delivery, and one from the second half. You will write on six texts, three texts for each context. For each text you will outline in 200 words why the text is a quality research source, and how it is relevant to design theory and the respective context. Prior to submission, you will undertake a number of in-class activities that will support and guide you in how to create an annotated bibliography.

Feedback will be delivered electronically 2 weeks after the submission date.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES1290 - Australian Design History","description":"

This course aims to develop your understanding, critical and aesthetic awareness of the history, cultural and philosophical stances that underpin a variety of Australian design objects and images. It provides an exploration of various pivotal periods of Australian design history from the beginnings of a culture of local unskilled as well as skilled artisans through to the 21st century notion of a professional, sustainable designer practice. Australian design history is contextualised by both local concerns about aesthetics, function, production and consumption and the wider influences of significant International movements and trends. Through an extensive study of Australian design history, various designers' work will be critically analysed considering both its cultural, aesthetic and practical worth to society and culture over time. A variety of learning activities are designed to assist you to develop research, writing and presentation skills through both individual and group assessment tasks. You are provided with the opportunity to further critique your own role as participants in 21st century consumer culture as well as to consider the influence that Australian design history could have on your future role as designers.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5e02eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961944","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Contemporary design museum object Critical analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

For this assignment, you will be visiting with the class in Week 2 the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences (Powerhouse Museum) where you will choose two Contemporary 21st Century design objects on display (provide illustrations) and complete a 2,500 word (max.) critical analysis that answers the following questions:

1. What was the target market? (Social & Cultural context)

2. Was it typical of other designs of the period? Why/why not? (Include visual comparisons) (Wide Context)

3. What past designs/designers influenced its design? Or is it a unique new invention? (Influences)

4. Do you think that it had a narrow or wide aesthetic appeal when it first appeared? (Aesthetics)

5. How has its context changed by becoming a ‘museum item’? (Context within a museum)

Guidelines: You can write about the above in any order; essay form is preferred over a subheading format as this style disrupts the flow of your discussion. Remember to include an introduction, paragraphs with one line between each (remember a paragraph contains one idea – a new idea needs a new paragraph), conclusion and bibliography. Remember to be consistent with your referencing and include a Reference list of all cited material used in your essay.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d602eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"de02eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de02eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5202eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Historic House Design Object Critical Analysis Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For this assignment, you will analyse one design object or image from an Australian historic house and discuss your and experts in the fields viewpoints on the significance of this design example to Australian National Heritage. You will then compare and contrast this historic design example to another similar example of contemporary Australian design and also discuss the significance of these design objects and images by critically analysing each within the context of related international design movements and trends of their time (word limit: 1,200).

Note: To write a successful critical analysis of your chosen design object, it is necessary to include some ‘authoritative’ views, as an academic essay should include supportive material from a variety of intellectual fully-referenced sources. As such, books and journals on design history, theory and museum collection studies in the library will be the main research source; however, the internet can be used if the original source of the material can be identified i.e. author, date, title, etc. It is not appropriate to just supply the website address although this will be a starting point for your research. Look for scholarly writing that includes quotes, references and that conextualises research from experts in the field. Critical Analysis Essays are to be submitted into Turnitin accessed through Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"de02eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de02eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f3961946","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e02eb5bdb213c50be4672f5f396194c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial class presentation - 30 minutes","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In groups (2 or 3 students), you will present a critical discussion of the documents, visuals and other resource material provided in Moodle on your group’s chosen tutorial topic. This presentation should be supported by research other than that provided in Moodle. The topics each week will cover a variety of historical and contemporary Australian design history and theory that relate to both the course assignments and lecture content. 

Structure of presentations: each presentation is a total of 30 minutes, it should include a 10 minute introductory discussion about the material provided in Moodle, followed by five talking points and a brief conclusion, and end with a 10-minute class activity and/or discussion.

You will also be required to submit a short summary (300 words) of your presentation/activity/discussion and any supporting documentation (e.g. powerpoint slides) on the day of your presentation.

contentlets.keywords: domain design,australian design history,australian cultural history,decorative arts,material culture
contentlets.description: This course aims to develop your understanding, critical and aesthetic awareness of the history, cultural and philosophical stances that underpin a variety of Australian design objects and images. It provides an exploration of various pivotal periods of Australian design history from the beginnings of a culture of local unskilled as well as skilled artisans through to the 21st century notion of a professional, sustainable designer practice. Australian design history is contextualised by both local concerns about aesthetics, function, production and consumption and the wider influences of significant International movements and trends. Through an extensive study of Australian design history, various designers' work will be critically analysed considering both its cultural, aesthetic and practical worth to society and culture over time. A variety of learning activities are designed to assist you to develop research, writing and presentation skills through both individual and group assessment tasks. You are provided with the opportunity to further critique your own role as participants in 21st century consumer culture as well as to consider the influence that Australian design history could have on your future role as designers.
contentlets.title: Australian Design History

contentlets.keywords: domain design,industry,collaborative design,design studio
contentlets.description: This course is an agile, industry focussed project that provides a platform for collaboration across real-world industry and stakeholder project possibilities. Collaboration and followship are the key drivers of the design process. You will experience the dynamics of individual achievement and contribution in a collaborative outcome.
contentlets.title: Design Studio 3 - Collaborative Industry/Stakeholder Project

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2101 - Design Studio 4 - Interdisciplinary Project","description":"

This is a culminating design course that encourages you to draw together insights and expertise from two or more specialisations from within the Design program. You may also collaborate with other creative or professional disciplines, subject to approval. You will respond to a socially-engaged design brief to investigate a given situation, design context, and nominated themes. Using professional studio practice models, you will work in collaborative teams, drawing on different skill sets and knowledge. An informed project proposal will be supported by rigorous research, concept development and appropriate material explorations. A final project presentation will address user needs, constraints and the synthesis of multiple areas of practice to generate unique and innovative outcomes.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2102 - Design Professional Practice","description":"

This course will help you develop essential skills to transition into the rapidly changing design industry through the principles of professionalism and a commercial grounding in the realities and complexities of design practice. By reflecting on your unique strengths and talents, you will begin to position yourself relative to the challenges of contemporary design practice to demonstrate your expertise for potential employers, clients and collaborators.


Through a combination of lectures, workshops, open dialogue and roleplaying, the course will cover design practice essentials ranging from understanding business and finance, legal and statutory constraints, business communication, self actualisation, interpersonal relations, and client and stakeholder management. By acknowledging the equally important roles of entrepreneurship, leadership and followship, you will be better prepared to navigate the design industry of the future.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2110 - 3D Visualisation 2: Virtual Worlds","description":"

This intermediate course within the 3D Visualisation disciplinary studio will help you explore 3D computer visualisations through the creation of a digital 3D environment. Building on the skills already acquired in the introductory course to create a 3D virtual asset in isolation, you will now create multiple assets before laying them out in a complete, fully realised virtual scene. To successfully complete this process, you will need to consider how assets engage and relate to each other and the space they inhabit. The creation of the virtual scene will be conceptually driven and supported by theoretical research. Engaging studio workshops will explore the full Computer-Generated Imagery (CGI) workflow with a particular emphasis on CGI lighting, rendering techniques and clear art direction. This course will provide you with an increased ability to apply the knowledge and skills that are used in the field of computer modelling and Computer-Generated visualisation to the creation of your own 3D virtual worlds.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"15a2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f3961963","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Previsualisation: Narrative and Reference gathering","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to actively engage with the process of research and previsualisation in preparation for the creation of a 3D Computer Generated Imagery scene. Students will be required to investigate, gather reference and use found and/or created objects to generate a narrative that will inform the construction and exploration of a 3D virtual scene. Students will interpret and construct a visual aesthetic using prototyping and testing informed by narrative, as well as an intermediate level of theoretical thinking and analysis.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"95a2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f3961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"95a2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5da2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f3961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Scene 3d Visualisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment will guide students to the realisation of a creative and original 3D virtual scene. Students will draw on the background research they have accumulated and take into consideration all tests they have carried out during the previsualisation phase. The final work will be an exploration of a resolved, narrative-driven environment with consideration of how the assets engage and relate to each other to create atmosphere. Students will evaluate their processes and final design outcomes and provide a written reflection on how they might improve the identified issues for any future 3D visualisation projects.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"95a2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9da2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f3961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d5a2a75fdb213c50be4672f5f396196a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2110.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2111 - 3D Visualisation 3: Interactive Environments","description":"

This advanced course within the 3D Visualisation disciplinary studio will provide you with the opportunity to immerse yourself in the field of computer modelling and computer-generated visualisation and refine your knowledge, methods and skills. Expanding in complexity and drawing on the skills already acquired in the preceding courses, you will design and create an experiential, explorable and 3D virtual world. Scholarly research will provide an informed foundation for the creation of a sophisticated, conceptually focussed virtual environment. Engaging studio workshops will explore the full computer-generated imagery workflow with a particular emphasis on how 3D assets engage and relate to each other in a realtime platform, low-poly modelling and a high level of art direction in the creation of your own virtual world.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"61d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961940","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Previsualisation: Narrative and Data Gathering","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to actively engage with and apply a range of research methodologies and previsualisation techniques and processes to the planning and creation of a 3D Computer Generated realtime environment. You will develop a self-directed project proposal that clearly defines your chosen design narrative and the aesthetic approach that will direct the ultimate creation of your 3D virtual environment for Assessment 2. Through a process of research, investigation and evaluation you will gather references, identify key objects and original assets relevant to your proposed environment. To assist in the refinement of your proposal, you will be asked to consider and incorporate the findings of all the data gathering you have carried out during the previsualisation phase.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e1d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"25d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Realtime Environment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment will see you realise a creative and original 3D realtime environment that draws on the research and evaluation you have undertaken in the previous assessment. The successful development and application of your 3D Computer Generated workflow will enable you to generate a final work which will be an exploration of a resolved, narrative-driven interactive realtime environment that includes the creation of original assets. You will ensure your design narrative and aesthetic approach informs all creative decisions in the making of your 3D environment, including acknowledging and responding to how your assets create context within this environment. You will evaluate your processes and final design outcomes and provide a written reflection.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutor. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e1d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e9d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9d26b9fdb213c50be4672f5f3961943","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2111.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2120 - Object 2: Objects and Place","description":"

This intermediate course within the Object disciplinary studio will introduce you to the contextual and relational significance of objects. Building on fundamental thinking-through-making skills acquired in the introductory Object 1 course, you will focus on the context of culture and place to examine social practices relating to dining rituals. Through this contextual lens, you will learn how to develop an understanding of the role of objects in facilitating social and meaningful interactions. Conceptual outcomes will be designed and made using digital technologies and craft processes. Central to the processes learned is the potential for objects to be produced as multiples using casting and 3D printing methods.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b9ebd6badb70f010fe4b322af4961910","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research & Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task introduces you to the contextual and relational significance of objects through conceptual provocations around notions of place. You will develop understandings of objects and place through the development of prototypes for an object or series of objects, and learn skills in conceptual thinking, historical and cultural analysis, digital fabrication and material investigations.

\n

Feedback will be provided in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on your project will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f1ebd6badb70f010fe4b322af4961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f9ebd6badb70f010fe4b322af4961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f9ebd6badb70f010fe4b322af4961912","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"35eb1abadb70f010fe4b322af4961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Studio Investigations & Design Resolution","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this assessment task you will continue to develop your ideas about the social object in relation to dining rituals by prototyping an object, or series of objects, using processes learned in the second half of the course. Prototyping, design iteration and material testing will form the focus of this assessment. You will learn how to visually articulate your ideas and to problem solve through construction methods and material engagements.

\n

Feedback will be provided in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on your project will be provided.

contentlets.keywords: domain design,object design,craft practice,jewellery,furniture,lighting,ceramics,social objects,cultural objects,relational principles,tableware,domestic objects,ritual objects,digital handmade,craft-led design,making,prototyping,responsible practice
contentlets.description: This intermediate course within the Object disciplinary studio will introduce you to the contextual and relational significance of objects. Building on fundamental thinking-through-making skills acquired in the introductory Object 1 course, you will focus on the context of culture and place to examine social practices relating to dining rituals. Through this contextual lens, you will learn how to develop an understanding of the role of objects in facilitating social and meaningful interactions. Conceptual outcomes will be designed and made using digital technologies and craft processes. Central to the processes learned is the potential for objects to be produced as multiples using casting and 3D printing methods.
contentlets.title: Object 2: Objects and Place

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2121 - Object 3: Objects and the World","description":"

In this advanced course within the Object disciplinary studio, you will explore design-nature relationships through objects and material-led enquiries. You will build on the hand-making and digital skills acquired in the introductory and intermediate Object 1 and 2 courses, developing your knowledge of materiality to engage with and critique ideas relating to ecologies and the natural world. Informed by ecological frameworks such as the issue of material resources or biophilic design influences you will develop material experimentation and prototypes to gain greater insight of your role as a responsible designer and agent of change.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"383d123edb70f010fe4b322af4961921","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Development & Resolution","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this assessment task you will develop your proposed design from Assessment Task 1 by creating a prototype or series of prototypes that responds to the impact of human activity on the natural world. Prototyping, design iteration and material testing will form the focus of this assessment. You will learn how to articulate your conceptual framework developed in the design proposal and to problem solve through construction methods and material engagements.

\n

Feedback will be provided in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on your design will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f03d123edb70f010fe4b322af4961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f43d123edb70f010fe4b322af4961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fc3d123edb70f010fe4b322af4961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fc3d123edb70f010fe4b322af4961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"053d123edb70f010fe4b322af49619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Form & Process","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task introduces you to issues of ecology through conceptual frameworks to examine the impact of human activity on the natural world. You will develop an awareness of ecological imperatives critical to responsible design practice through the development of a design proposal for an object or series of objects. The task will further develop skills in hand-making and digital fabrication methods by involving material experimentation and conceptual explorations.

\n

Feedback will be provided in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on your design will be provided.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2130 - Experience 2: Spaces of Exhibition","description":"

This intermediate course within the Experience disciplinary studio will explore the possibilities of exhibition spaces as active sites for participation and collaboration. Building on foundational knowledge and skills acquired in the introductory course, you will explore the cultures of display that influence exhibition practice. It investigates strategies employed by exhibition designers to frame objects and ideas in order to communicate their meaning to a diverse participating public. More than this, you will be encouraged as a designer to be an agent of change – provoking active engagement with collections and cultural spaces. The studio-based classes will explore ideas and theories for designing for museums and galleries. You will develop a creative inquiry-based around narrative composition and sequencing of spaces, and will learn about the integration of mediated experiences and technologies as an important element in contemporary exhibition practice. Adopting an iterative and collaborative methodology you will propose display strategies and prototype designs with consideration of different materials and constructions methods, that can ultimately reframe a visitor’s experience of ideas, objects and spaces.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bd032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961902","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Through group work and using an iterative design process, you and your team will negotiate a design to be prototyped (selected from the pitch presentations). You will work collaboratively to fabricate this at 1:1 scale.

In-progress advice will be delivered informally during tutorials and sessions in the workshop with formal feedback provided in the form of written response and grading following submission of the prototype (and supporting technical information).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f9032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f9032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"35032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f396190a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Concept Pitch","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Working for the duration of the semester on one design project for an exhibition, the first assessment focuses on conceptual ideation and planning for this experience. It includes the development of a distinct display strategy. The presentation will take the form of short verbal presentation (pitch-style) with supporting visual documentation.

Formative feedback is to be provided in class from your peers and tutor, with formal graded feedback supplied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f1032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b9032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Design Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

In this assessment you will finalise your design for your exhibition, (incorporating the feedback from your audience evaluation session) You are asked to present your completed exhibition design including lighting design, object/experience layouts and a set of documentation drawings to communicate the developed design. 

In-progress advice will be delivered informally during tutorials with formal feedback provided in the form of written response and grading following final submission of the presentation and documentation set.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f1032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f9032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f9032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fd032fdfdb213c50be4672f5f396190e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2130.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2131 - Experience 3: Spaces for Performance","description":"

This advanced course within the Experience disciplinary studio will explore the relationships between people, space, spectacle and culture. Focusing on events as rich, multifaceted sites of experience, you will develop and test ideas and conditions for heightened and collective experiences.


Through considered design for a performance, you will continue to hone both analogue and digital skills to an advanced level to represent and communicate your research, ideation and development process. Additional knowledge and skills relevant to the theatre, film, exhibition and event industries will be developed to convey complex (and often unscripted) narrative structures as well as atmosphere and effect.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"df23ab13db613c50be4672f5f3961965","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collective Encounters","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment task asks you to develop a collective experience of public performance based on one of your responses to Assessment Task 1. With this assessment you are to convey the complexity of collective encounter, and consider and communicate multiple individual’s experience of your event space.

The iteration and extension of your initial concept, and design resolution through a project presentation and accompanying documentation will be key outcomes of the assessment task. Research and project development will be evidenced through a comprehensive project report and documentation set.

Formative feedback will be provided regularly in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative feedback and assessment of your project and documentation will be provided digitally upon submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d723ab13db613c50be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df23ab13db613c50be4672f5f3961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b23ab13db613c50be4672f5f396196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Public performance – a project proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment Task 1 asks you to research and select from a range of public performance typologies for presentation. You are also asked to develop four experiential futures that explore scenarios for current and future encounters and engagement. Research and project development will be evidenced through a short, curated presentation and comprehensive process journal.

Formative feedback will be given on a short presentation of Part A - your selected public performance. Summative feedback and assessment of your project iterations will be provided digitally upon submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d723ab13db613c50be4672f5f3961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d723ab13db613c50be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9f23ab13db613c50be4672f5f3961968","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2131.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Through considered design for a performance, you will continue to hone both analogue and digital skills to an advanced level to represent and communicate your research, ideation and development process. Additional knowledge and skills relevant to the theatre, film, exhibition and event industries will be developed to convey complex (and often unscripted) narrative structures as well as atmosphere and effect.
