Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2140 - Graphics 2: Identity and Form","description":"

This intermediate course within the Graphics disciplinary studio will introduce you to research-based responses to developing a visual identity in the context of a broader understanding of brand design. You will build on the typography and image fundamentals acquired in the introductory course, and develop an understanding of how to apply strategic thinking to your design process when developing visual identities and sophisticated graphic systems across a range of media. Your approaches will be framed by theory, as well as a consideration of end-users, naming and tone of voice, and practical issues such as copyright. Your knowledge of visual identity will be further advanced by applying graphic solutions to three-dimensional forms, as well as developing an understanding of issues such as materiality, life-cycle analysis, and responsible practices such as sustainability and ethics in the context of graphic design.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"89536b53db613c50be4672f5f3961917","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Packaging Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task asks you to reconsider the packaging of a product with an emphasis on the application of graphic solutions to a 3-dimensional form. You will analyse an existing product in terms of life cycle, sustainability and ethical considerations. In the context of this research you will then be able to justify your design decisions for a new design proposal. Prototyping and documentation will be central to an iterative design process.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on the design and documentation of prototypes, in-class presentation, process journal, and course reflection will be provided digitally.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c5536b53db613c50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cd536b53db613c50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd536b53db613c50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"81536b53db613c50be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Visual Identity Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task asks you to reconsider the visual identity of an organisation. You will engage with communication strategies, audience and implementation across a range of print and digital deliverables. Concept development, design iteration and resolution, and the development of a professional presentation will be key outcomes of the assessment task. This assessment task will maintain a focus on developing typographic skills. Research, scholarly enquiry and experimentation will be evidenced through a comprehensive and curated process journal.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on your visual identity design, in-class presentation, visual journal, and course reflection will be provided digitally.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2141 - Graphics 3: Place and Space","description":"

This advanced course within the Graphics disciplinary studio will extend the skills you have developed in the introductory and intermediate courses into three-dimensional places and spaces, with an emphasis on research and critical thinking. You will develop interpretive narratives through graphic interventions, alongside strategies for the installation of your responses. Expressed through a design proposition and subsequent development of a graphic design project, we will continue our established disciplinary focus on typographic skills alongside a broad range of image making techniques. By the end of the course, you will have a strong portfolio piece that reflects your emerging graphic design voice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"96832b93db613c50be4672f5f396190b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Developing a Narrative: Visual Research Methods","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment Task 01 asks students to select and respond to a location with a strong community connection or compelling history. Students will identify and communicate an issue that has impacted on the location, or their response to that place as a designer. This will take the form of a short pitch on which they will be given formative feedback. Using a range of visual and design research methods, students will then formulate and present a design proposition which will form the basis of the second assessment task.

Research and project development will be evidenced through a comprehensive and curated process journal.

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on the proposition, presentation, and process journal will be provided digitally.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d2832b93db613c50be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"da832b93db613c50be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"12832b93db613c50be4672f5f3961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Deploying Narratives: Interpretation and Wayfinding","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Using the location identified in the previous assessment and accompanying research, students will develop a graphic narrative expressed through words and images and consider how to apply that narrative into the place/space. Students will map a series of paths to the location, and will implement a hierarchical system of graphic interventions to signpost the user’s journey, decision points and arrival at that location. There will also be consideration given to the users’ navigation of the space. Students will be expected to employ critical thinking and user testing to inform their project outcome. 

Research and project development will be evidenced through a comprehensive and curated process journal.

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback on the project, presentation, process journal, and course reflection will be provided digitally.

contentlets.keywords: domain design,graphic design,wayfinding,placemaking,design narrative,narrative spaces,design research,interpretation design,responsible practice,critical thinking,visual ethnography,visual research methods
contentlets.description: This advanced course within the Graphics disciplinary studio will extend the skills you have developed in the introductory and intermediate courses into three-dimensional places and spaces, with an emphasis on research and critical thinking. You will develop interpretive narratives through graphic interventions, alongside strategies for the installation of your responses. Expressed through a design proposition and subsequent development of a graphic design project, we will continue our established disciplinary focus on typographic skills alongside a broad range of image making techniques. By the end of the course, you will have a strong portfolio piece that reflects your emerging graphic design voice.
contentlets.title: Graphics 3: Place and Space

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2150 - Interaction 2: Design Methodologies","description":"

This intermediate course within the Interaction disciplinary studio will introduce you to the formal methodologies of interaction design. Building on the principles and practices acquired in the introductory course, a holistic, situated approach to technology will be used as a framework to look at how new designs work and are used in industry. You will examine design probes, need finding and user evaluation studies, and investigate case studies to understand how specific companies and individual designers innovate, adapt and respond to multiple constraints.  Through the implementation of iterative design processes such as the interaction design lifecycle model, you will learn to evaluate the feasibility of projects and adapt project goals.  Beginning with identifying users’ needs, design development, prototyping, and testing of new designs, your work will culminate in a working prototype, communicated through text, video and/or interactive demonstrations to clearly explain the design concept.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"58c3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Functional Prototype and Pilot Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The focus of this assessment is to work in your groups to refine the functional prototype and conduct user evaluation with real-users. It is essential to demonstrate and communicate the project’s design process, ideas, solutions and evaluation outcomes. The first step of this group assessment is to refine your project’s prototype to allow it to be semi- to fully functional, thus making it ready for user evaluations. The prototype needs to demonstrate the design solution and how the user can operate and interact with it. Each group will select an appropriate evaluation method for their project and will have the option to collect both objective and/or subjective measurements. You will then analyse the collected data and prepare a short presentation that highlights the project’s overall design process and a summary of the outcomes. Presentations should clearly explain the design concept via effective visual and verbal communication approaches.

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided digitally    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"94c3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9cc3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18c3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f3961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Requirements Elicitation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to identify and establish a set of user needs and requirements for a specific user group. The first part of this assessment is undertaken individually, where you will work on identifying possible intended users in response to a designated theme; considering what users need and what possible problems they face in relation to the theme. The core part of this assessment is to use a set of techniques to identify user requirements, such as conducting interviews and observational user studies. The second part of this assessment is to work in groups to plan your project, narrow down possible design problem/s and consolidate the user requirements. 

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided digitally.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"94c3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9cc3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54c3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f3961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Low-Fidelity Prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment builds on the previous assessment and focuses on establishing possible design solutions based on the gathered user requirements. As an initial step, you will research the theory, related literature and previous studies that are relevant to your group’s project. You will then engage in a creative “hands-on” iterative process to generate possible low-fidelity prototypes. The process involves several steps that include defining hypotheses on the theory of use, refining one (or a combination) of the defined hypotheses, sketching/generating wireframes, building mock-ups, producing possible low-fidelity prototype/s, and planning for testing the prototype/s with real-users. This assessment is presented as a report and a live demonstration of the low-fidelity prototype/s. Your report is to be submitted individually via Moodle and the low-fidelity prototype is to be demonstrated in class. 

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussion with peers and tutors. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided digitally.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"94c3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9cc3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dcc3e7d3db613c50be4672f5f3961943","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2150.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2151 - Interaction 3: Emerging Applications","description":"

This advanced course within the Interaction disciplinary studio will introduce you to some of the state-of-the-art emerging applications in interaction design. Throughout the course, you will examine the importance of human physical, social and cognitive abilities to inform the design process. The course focuses on the key emerging technological areas that are transforming current interaction design practice, including artificial intelligence, conversational interfaces, robotic interfaces, and mixed reality environments.


In this course, you will undertake an in-depth project that focuses on one of the identified key emerging technological areas. Your main task is to work through the interaction design process, by building on the concepts, methodologies and technical skills developed in Interaction 1 and 2, to derive design prototypes for a designated theme. In particular, your project will demonstrate an emphasis on relevant human capabilities and their successful integration into your design prototypes.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"37e3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961926","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research into Existing Creative Technologies","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Research two existing creative technologies. Create two parallel posters with supporting graphics. Questions to answer:
- list one or more technological affordances
- list its limitations or dependencies (and perhaps where its application has failed)             - give one or more examples of its use
- for those examples, discuss critical design issues using analytical concepts (from IxD course, or of your own research)
- consider the ‘ecosystem’ of users, devices, and services involved.
- brainstorm some new areas where this tech could transform a domain of your choice.
- reference at least one technical paper, one theoretical discussion paper, and one application example.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48f3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"48f3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"00f3a717db613c50be4672f5f396192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design Prototype and Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Includes group work (50%) and individual work (50%).
Create a design and rapid prototype, presented as a 10 minute group presentation / demonstration and an ndividual report covering design development.
Aas a group, use a collaborative ideation process and document it (you should reiterate the ideation stage again after gathering user needs, and revisit designs as a group throughout). The following tasks can be divided unevenly amongst team members:
- gather user-needs using a range of research methods and build user profiles.
- develop design sketches and concepts.
- research feasibility, introduce new constraints, and identify ways that successful designs could work. Continue to consider against expectations of users.
- develop initial prototypes and analyse using ‘in house’ methods (heuristic analysis, walkthroughs).
- establish what questions these prototypes pose about successful user adoption.
As a group, collate your ideas into a more detailed rich prototype / mockup which aims to communicate your concept. This may involve a user journey reported as a video (due week 9).
Iterate your designs individually, forking from the original group idea, looking at finer detail issues or researching design alternatives.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"40f3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"40f3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48f3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"48f3a717db613c50be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"88f3a717db613c50be4672f5f396192d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2151.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2160 - Textiles 2: Experimental Textiles","description":"

This intermediate course within the Textiles disciplinary studio involves experimentation, research and design development for innovative and experimental applications of textile designs. Experimentation and investigation are central to creating original, innovative and contemporary textile designs, and this course allows you to develop your own experimental approach to your textile design practice. By building on textile fundamentals acquired in the introductory course, you will also develop digital textile design and diverse making techniques, underpinned by more advanced design development processes. Working with industry standard briefs will allow you to take into consideration the requirements of designing for a commercial organisation. In addition, the course traces the ways in which designs can be translated into sustainable outcomes for production by hand, machine or digitally. This commitment to sustainability and social engagement in the course enables you to analyse contemporary issues, understand a designer’s responsibility, and know how to respond to professional design briefs responsibly, ethically and with cultural acknowledgement. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4f142757db613c50be4672f5f396199e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental Textiles: Experimentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task requires you to select an area of textiles to research, explore and experiment with to understand what can be done with selected materials, processes and techniques. The aim of this task is to create innovative and sustainable designs, objects and outcomes in textiles; to speculate and re-imagine existing design solution to open and expand design possibilities in textile outcomes. The task will require reviewing historical and/or existing textile traditions to extrapolate how these could be expanded or subverted to take these technologies forward. This project requires diverse experimentation across a selection of materials and processes; innovative and explorative risk-taking to explore proposal ideas and concepts; to document current practice and establish a series of experiments.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular bases in studio through discussions with peers, in groups and with lecturers. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"43142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental Textiles: Design Range","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment task allows you to translate your experimentation into a design range. You will be able to refine your task 1 prototype and develop a finished realisation of your proposal underpinned by materials and conceptual research. All design ranges will require innovative, sustainable design solutions, creative works, experimentation or any other practice-based outcomes and critical analysis of your practice and design outcomes. This assessment focuses on the outcomes of your practice and it should demonstrate tight integration with your research.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular bases in studio through discussions with peers, in groups and with lecturers. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"43142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"43142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f142757db613c50be4672f5f39619a7","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES2160.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2161 - Textiles 3: Future Textiles","description":"

This advanced course within the Textiles disciplinary studio will encourage you to actively engage with textile materials, processes and technologies to create novel responses to global and/or local issues or developments. Building on the skills already acquired in the introductory and intermediate courses, you will now identify a problem, issue or opportunity to contextualise your development of textiles. Working through an iterative design process, you will produce innovative design solutions that demonstrate a strong emphasis on personal expression and experimentation both in the use of design stimulus, materials and techniques. Studio sessions will encourage you to expand your aesthetic awareness and take unconventional approaches to textiles practice for fashion, interior, exterior or product contexts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a544e397db613c50be4672f5f3961989","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Creating Future Textiles","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment task allows you to translate your ideas from Assessment one into a set of textile samples or prototypes. You will be able to select and refine a research direction from your Assessment one project work and conduct a series of experiments that lead to a finalised textile outcome. Your samples or prototypes must acknowledge responsible practice through the consideration of ethical, social, cultural and environmental impacts of textiles practice, and be supported by a critical analysis of your practice and design outcomes.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussions with peers, in groups and with lecturers. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b144e397db613c50be4672f5f396198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b144e397db613c50be4672f5f396198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b944e397db613c50be4672f5f396198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b944e397db613c50be4672f5f396198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7944e397db613c50be4672f5f396198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exploring Future Textiles","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment requires you to identify a global and/or local issue, problem or opportunity and compile, analyse and evaluate primary and secondary research that will inform the production of innovative design solutions in Assessment two.  The aim of this task is to conduct scholarly research which you will analyse and evaluate to develop a set of future textile scenarios; this will involve reflecting on traditional or historical and/or new and emerging materials, techniques and processes and how these may be applied to the specific problem, issue or opportunity identified through your research. This project requires interpreting research to develop design ideas that will inform the project work for Assessment two.

\n

Feedback will be provided on a regular basis in studio through discussions with peers, in groups and with lecturers. Summative assessment and feedback will be provided.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2180 - Creative Thinking Processes","description":"

Have you ever had an idea that you wanted to push and develop further, but you weren’t sure how to do it? This course will introduce you to some of the many tools that can facilitate creative thinking. The processes of analysis can help to extend possibilities beyond predictable outcomes, and the same thinking tool can be used across many different disciplines to create new, more integrated and original options and ideas. We will explore visual, verbal and physical ways of transforming ordinary ideas into fantastic ones. Using taught techniques such as the Synectic Pinball Game you will learn to understand more clearly what happens when the creative mind is at work.


We will test the principles of interconnectivity, bisociation (conceptual blending), non-linear (associative) thinking, and use maps, models and metaphors to develop your creative thinking through research, analysis and application of these models to your own ideas. Many famous creative thinkers have used a wide range of processes that we will critically explore and apply.


An important part of understanding and applying the creative process is an examination of how we learn, and how to facilitate the best possible conditions and environments for working in innovative and creative ways. The balance between strategic planning and goal-free approaches to creative processes will be analysed and discussed in relation to the applied research of Professor Teresa Amabile and Professor Tina Seelig amongst others.


Collaborative theory and practice have at their core the potential to extend and enhance outcomes in multi-disciplinary thinking. Relating to this, the model of Combined Divergence will be introduced, and applied to a project based analysis of the overlaps between critical and creative thinking methodologies.


This course is a part of the of ADADA2 Creativity and Innovation Stream, and is open to students from all faculties and disciplines. You are also able to enrol in this course separately as an elective or general education course. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a07463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619f8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2. The Synectic Pinball Machine","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The Synectic Pinball Machine is an imaginary model that employs visual, verbal and physical processes to take an idea (the ball) beyond predictable thinking outcomes (through the application of alternative creative pathways). As a Team, select a contemporary issue currently being debated in the newspapers, and process it as a Team exercise in brainstorming through the Synectic Pinball Machine. Collectively summarise in Assessment Task 2 what new and original options, outcomes, solutions and creative ideas this produced in both visual and verbal formats.


Feedback will be delivered to students within 2 weeks of submission of an assessment, and will be uploaded into a private area of the course website. Feedback will consist of a completed assessment rubric indicating the student’s performance against the assessable criteria and a final project grade, and may also include an audio mp3 file containing comments from the lecturer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"607463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"607463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"687463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"207463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1. A New Idea","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

By researching and exploring a key creative person, we can become more informed about: what traits made someone creative; what environments existed to make certain periods have high creativity (and conversely, what environments or conditions held certain individuals back); what processes of creative thinking a key creative person used, and finally, how these three things (traits, environment, processes) integrated together to make the life of that individual notable for her/his creative achievements.

We will also continue to discuss the differences and similarities between creativity, innovation and critical thinking - many well known key creative people in history have shown outstanding abilities in all three of these areas. In this illustrated 2000 word Assessment Task 1 you are asked to choose one key creative historical person to research. Discuss their contributions in relation to their traits, environment and processes. You may choose someone from any discipline area, but they should not be alive - this allows you to discuss their complete life and creative contribution. Please structure your illustrated essay/discussion paper using these four sub-headings in the following suggested order:

  • Context - Environment and upbringing/personal history/introduction?
  • Concept - Ideas your chosen person had and why (creativity)?
  • Content - How they went about making their ideas a reality (processes)?
  • Constraints - How they overcame difficulties, and problem-solved (thinking).

Feedback will be delivered to students within 2 weeks of submission of an assessment, and will be uploaded into a private area of the course website. Feedback will consist of a completed assessment rubric indicating the student’s performance against the assessable criteria and a final project grade, and may also include an audio mp3 file containing comments from the lecturer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"607463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"687463d7db613c50be4672f5f39619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c74a3d7db613c50be4672f5f3961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3. Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment Task 3 asks you to consider, the information introduced in the lectures, readings and discussions to date in the course as a whole. These broadly encompass briefs and ideas which can be applied to develop your creative thinking, and they also include different types of processes. The model of thinking applied in Assessment Task 3 is a TRIAD Process first described in Design Synectics by Nicholas Roukes: Refer / Reflect / Reconstruct:

  • Refer to the Lectures, Readings and Discussions, and to research further the links and references within them, selecting areas which interest you.
  • Reflect on the information you select/research and find most interesting in order to relate it to your own personal experiences and/or areas of study. It is important to be able to see how some of the course information and types of creative techniques can be useful to the different careers and kinds of work you will each experience in the future. We tend to remember best what we have a direct experience of, which is why you are asked here not just to think about a creativity technique but to actively apply it in some way.
  • Reconstruct in the form of a summary report what you have learned, discussed and applied to an area of your life eg family, career, study, sport, etc. The Assessment Task 3 Research Report asks you to give at least ONE EXAMPLE of a creativity technique/process selected from the course, being applied as an example to an aspect of your life. In your Reconstruction, reflect on whether or not the technique/process produced the outcome you expected.

Feedback will be delivered to students within 2 weeks of submission of an assessment, and will be uploaded into a private area of the course website. Feedback will consist of a completed assessment rubric indicating the student’s performance against the assessable criteria and a final project grade, and may also include an audio mp3 file containing comments from the lecturer.

contentlets.keywords: domain design,creativity,innovation,creative,thinking
contentlets.description:
Have you ever had an idea that you wanted to push and develop further, but you weren’t sure how to do it? This course will introduce you to some of the many tools that can facilitate creative thinking. The processes of analysis can help to extend possibilities beyond predictable outcomes, and the same thinking tool can be used across many different disciplines to create new, more integrated and original options and ideas. We will explore visual, verbal and physical ways of transforming ordinary ideas into fantastic ones. Using taught techniques such as the Synectic Pinball Game you will learn to understand more clearly what happens when the creative mind is at work.

We will test the principles of interconnectivity, bisociation (conceptual blending), non-linear (associative) thinking, and use maps, models and metaphors to develop your creative thinking through research, analysis and application of these models to your own ideas. Many famous creative thinkers have used a wide range of processes that we will critically explore and apply.

An important part of understanding and applying the creative process is an examination of how we learn, and how to facilitate the best possible conditions and environments for working in innovative and creative ways. The balance between strategic planning and goal-free approaches to creative processes will be analysed and discussed in relation to the applied research of Professor Teresa Amabile and Professor Tina Seelig amongst others.

Collaborative theory and practice have at their core the potential to extend and enhance outcomes in multi-disciplinary thinking. Relating to this, the model of Combined Divergence will be introduced, and applied to a project based analysis of the overlaps between critical and creative thinking methodologies.

This course is a part of the of ADADA2 Creativity and Innovation Stream, and is open to students from all faculties and disciplines. You are also able to enrol in this course separately as an elective or general education course.
contentlets.title: Creative Thinking Processes

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES2200 - Design History and Theory 3","description":"

This course is the third of four courses within the Design History and Theory core. It builds on the knowledge and skills that you have acquired during the preceding courses. During the course you will explore the ideas of positions in design and in order to do so will examine issues of personal and professional identities through the lens of race, gender, nationality. Through a series of engaging lectures and tutorials, you will discuss how the modes of designing have changed through time and ask the question “what does it mean to be a designer?” By engaging with contemporary design theories and the histories that have informed them, you will analyse the notion of design agency in the evolution of social, economic, technological and political contexts, both past and present.


This course will enable you to further develop your vocabulary and skills in order to interpret and critically engage with contemporary design debates. Upon successful completion of this course, you will be able to position yourself and situate your design practice in broader socio-political and cultural contexts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8174a3d7db613c50be4672f5f396194a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

You will write a reflective essay identifying, assessing, discussing and proposing how you position yourself and situate your practice as a designer. Your reflection will be sustained by scholarly research. The reflective essay will allow you to discuss your personal position and to demonstrate your understanding and working knowledge of historical and contemporary theories. You will receive a summative written feedback from your tutor who will consider your ability to select, examine and reference scholarly sources, offer historical and contemporary contextualization to your views, demonstrate critical and analytical thinking, and synthesis and communication of ideas.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c574a3d7db613c50be4672f5f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cd74a3d7db613c50be4672f5f396194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cd74a3d7db613c50be4672f5f396194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8974a3d7db613c50be4672f5f3961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Debate","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Student teams will debate a defined design related issue. Each debate will present the affirmative and negative position on the issue.

The in-class debate will be preceded by a 3-week collaborative research process. Groups will discuss the issue and prepare a proposition by researching and lining up relevant data and argumentation. Throughout this process you will gather written and visual sources to support your argument. In class, the group will formally present your team’s position. You will listen to the presentation of the opposing group and develop the response in light of your group position.

A debate will ensue, with a moderator to chair and an adjudicator (or adjudicators) who will formatively assess the groups’ debating performances. The tutor will provide each group with a formative oral feedback addressing the argument construction, debate abilities and capacity to incorporate the opposing sides’ views.

Each group member will be asked to submit an individually written document outlining the argument, rationale and bibliography for which you will receive a summative written feedback. The feedback will consider your group research, referencing and communication skills and critical analysis.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES3100 - Design Studio 5 - Design Studio Proposal","description":"

This course requires you to generate a rigorous, detailed and theoretically based design project proposal, brief and schematic design for development in Design Studio 6. Applied research, investigation and reflection on the nature of contemporary design practice will inform this self-initiated project. The project will be positioned in a real context and provide you with further experience of the multi-disciplinary nature of design. It will be developed in conjunction with selected professionals and/or with a client who presents a real-life design problem. The design proposals must address complex contextual issues and fully address the constraints of the brief. You will work collaboratively in studio to develop a peer mentoring culture through critique and evaluation.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES3101 - Design Studio 6 - Design Studio Project","description":"

This culminating capstone studio project will extend from research and development undertaken in Design Studio 5 through to the translation of research findings into realised design solutions in the form of a major project. The completed project will demonstrate the synthesis of previously learned disciplinary specialisations, theory, research, and practice studies with reference to more than one studio area in the finished project. You will be required to develop a rigorous and legible design process, investigation of additional areas of knowledge, to demonstrate design management of the project. You will show leadership in the social, ethical and environmental impact of your design solution and apply your skills to clear documentation and presentation of an integrated design outcome.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES3190 - Mapping and Design Laboratory (mad.lab)","description":"

mad.lab is an interdisciplinary elective course run in the Chinese city of Chongqing and open to art, design, media and architecture students. The course immerses students in an intensive three-week program where they (1) work with local and international industry professionals on real world industry briefs developed with project stakeholders including Chongqing industry and government (2) collaborate with their peers from local academic institutions; and (3) engage directly with the citizens and unique culture of Chongqing. The course includes, lectures, peer and industry critique, field trips, collaborations and meetings with the art & design, architecture and urban development industry sectors and cultural institutions, local communities and public. The course culminates in an exhibition where students pitch their project outcomes to local industry and government representatives.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9df4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f3961959","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 - mad.lab Studio Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

mad.lab Studio Project invites students to respond to an industry driven creative brief. The approach is to explore Chongqing using mapping as a research methodology to create urban narratives through experimentation, observation, story telling, journeys, film, audio-visual recordings and a range of cartographic techniques and explorations. These activities will address a site-specific problem framed by the local project partners. mad.lab Studio Project challenges participants to consider question like:

Can we engage in mapping as design research to observe, understand and articulate urban narratives, dream the future, and think critically and collaboratively about the city, place and it’s unique identities?

How might we map complex city environments as a means to understand urban context, identify problems and opportunities to develop innovative design proposals and interventions?

mad.lab strives to explore how the desires, culture and behaviors of people shape the urban fabric. In mad.lab Studio Project you will engage in a detailed research-based mapping process drawing on a range of morphological, interpretive, critical, emotional, experiential, derive-like strategies to record the thoroughfares, pathways, hierarchies, continuities and discontinuities of a selected site or urban space. The process of creating and reinterpreting these mappings of the city will inform and support a design proposal.

A full brief and supporting documents will be supplied via Moodle and briefings will be given prior to departure at orientation sessions and by project stakeholders at the commencement of the studio.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"95f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f396195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"95f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f396195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9df4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f396195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a5f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f396195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f3961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 - mad.lab introduction – Self-mapping for collaboration","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Prior to departure students will prepare two presentations in the form of maps designed to facilitate a mutual awareness of the diverse experiences, talents, aspirations, interests and personal backgrounds held within the mad.lab participant cohort. The objective is to introduce the student to the mad.lab cohort. These mappings provide a mechanism for establishing mutual understanding between the cohort members and are a springboard for emergent collaborative relationships.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"95f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f396195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f396195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 - mad.lab Studio Reflection and Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The mad.lab Studio Reflection and Evaluation is a 1000-word designed and illustrated documentation of your personal learning journey during mad.lab.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES3200 - Design History and Theory 4","description":"

This is the fourth and final course in the Design History and Theory core of the Bachelor of Design program. In this course, you will apply the knowledge and skills you have gained in Design History & Theory 1, 2 and 3 across national design histories, global design contexts, design positionality and broader contemporary social and cultural challenges to situate your practice within the expanded field of creative and cultural industries. This course will introduce you to the diverse views, ideas and practices of contemporary design stakeholders who contribute to making and thinking design in an expanded field including journalists, curators, managers, policy makers, researchers, educators, heritage and conservation specialists. The course will help you better understand how design cultures have evolved and critically evaluate a broad spectrum of positions that design stakeholders have occupied in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. At the successful completion of this course, you will be able to identify diverse and alternative career pathways to engage with and through design and effectively communicate your design position, values and philosophy to the wider world.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3df4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f39619c1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design conversations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In small groups you will interview a professional working in a creative or cultural industry of your choice about their professional practice. You will interrogate their professional philosophy, ethics and values. You will record the conversation, communicate it through a designed artefact (brochure, video, storyboard etc.) and discuss them with your peers during in class presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"31f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"31f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"39f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"39f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79f4af5bdb613c50be4672f5f39619c9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design statement - Into the world","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task you will produce a public facing design statement that will introduce you and your practice to the wider world. You will research and identify historical and theoretical references that have been formative in your learning and professional development. To communicate your professional position to the world you will use a medium of your choice – podcast, video presentation, written statement etc.

of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES4101 - Design Honours Studio Research Project 1","description":"

Design Honours Research Project 1 is the first in a sequence of two Honours research courses designed to support you in developing your Honours research project. In this course, you will plan and critically develop a theoretical and practice-led research project that is directly related to the concepts, materials and processes and ideas emerging from your design practice. You will experiment and prototype design propositions and develop a written dissertation that will be further developed in DDES4102 Design Honours Research project 2. This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary design practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, fostering a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c4256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f3961989","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

In this task, you will deliver a 10 minute presentation (in studio) to articulate your research question(s), focus and approach. The purpose of this task is to identify the key questions that will propel your creative explorations and inquiries throughout your honours research project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c4256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f396198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cc256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f3961989","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"48256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f396198c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Studio Project and Pitch","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

In this task, you will present the initial outcomes of your design studio practice. At this early stage of your year-long research project, these outcomes may include resolved outcomes, work in progress and sketches/prototypes for future works. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c4256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f396198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cc256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f396198a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c0256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f3961990","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES4101.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

In this course, you will plan and critically develop a theoretical and practice-led research project that is directly related to the concepts, materials and processes and ideas emerging from your design practice. You will experiment and prototype design propositions and develop a written dissertation that will be further developed in DDES4102 Design Honours Research project 2. This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary design practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, fostering a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.

of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES4102 - Design Honours Studio Research Project 2","description":"

Design Honours Research Project 2 is the final of two Honours research courses designed to support you in developing and delivering your self-guided Honours research project. In this course, you will continue to critically develop your theoretical and/or practice-led research project realised in DDES4101 Design Honours Research Project 1, in relation to both your design practice, and your scholarly research framework and written dissertation. You will then resolve your research project into a sophisticated, professional design outcome supported by a written thesis. This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary design practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery and alignment to industry. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, run over two consecutive terms, so as to allow time for experimentation, development and exploration ahead of the final outcomes that constitute the majority of your Honours grade. The studio course fosters a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"14256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f39619d7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, you will write a 5000-word thesis addressing the research component of your Honours Project. This should include an outline of the finalised area of focus for your research, demonstrating clear critical thinking throughout, and where relevant should describe how you have applied practice-led research to address this area of focus.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"94256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"94256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9c256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f39619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"98256f9bdb613c50be4672f5f39619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this task, you will present the final outcomes of your studio research. The Final Project will be assessed through a 15-minute presentation of your research and associated final practice-based outcomes produced throughout Design Honours Studio Research Projects 1 and 2. The presentation will be followed by questions and feedback from your assessors.

This course introduces students to a range of philosophical, conceptual and theoretical methods and frameworks to help students develop their research skills and locate their design practice that critically reflects on contemporary design contexts. It is designed to help students concurrently undertake a substantial honours level research project.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES9901 - Designing and Experiencing Immersion","description":"

Virtual experiences and immersive environments are increasingly becoming an integrated aspect of today’s work, study, and entertainment practices. The rapid emergence and application of these technologies raises important questions about how they are best designed to maximise the potential of these experiences. Why, when, and where is it appropriate to incorporate and design for immersive experiences? How is immersion effectively designed, constructed, and experienced?


This course will explore the phenomenon of immersion design from historical, visual and aesthetic frameworks. You will also examine emergent technologies and recent neuroscientific understandings about the subjective perception of immersion.


Using this knowledge, you will evaluate the effectiveness of a range of immersion experiences from different industry sectors. Using an expanded understanding of the principles of immersive design from the theory and practical experiences in the course, you will have the opportunity to design your own immersive experiences.


**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

contentlets.description:
Virtual experiences and immersive environments are increasingly becoming an integrated aspect of today’s work, study, and entertainment practices. The rapid emergence and application of these technologies raises important questions about how they are best designed to maximise the potential of these experiences. Why, when, and where is it appropriate to incorporate and design for immersive experiences? How is immersion effectively designed, constructed, and experienced?

This course will explore the phenomenon of immersion design from historical, visual and aesthetic frameworks. You will also examine emergent technologies and recent neuroscientific understandings about the subjective perception of immersion.

Using this knowledge, you will evaluate the effectiveness of a range of immersion experiences from different industry sectors. Using an expanded understanding of the principles of immersive design from the theory and practical experiences in the course, you will have the opportunity to design your own immersive experiences.

**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

As we become increasingly compelled throughout our daily interactions to work or engage with digital and automated systems, we need to remain mindful of their purpose and impact on our lives. This course will help you understand how and why humans engage with immersive environments and technology systems in order to make better and more effective use of their potential.


Human cognition, performance and behaviour will be analysed across fully synthetic and virtual environments, as well as live and mixed reality contexts. You will examine ergonomic factors and how they impact performance in addition to more complex cognitive human responses, evolving human-machine relationships and next generation AI.


**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

contentlets.description:
As we become increasingly compelled throughout our daily interactions to work or engage with digital and automated systems, we need to remain mindful of their purpose and impact on our lives. This course will help you understand how and why humans engage with immersive environments and technology systems in order to make better and more effective use of their potential.

Human cognition, performance and behaviour will be analysed across fully synthetic and virtual environments, as well as live and mixed reality contexts. You will examine ergonomic factors and how they impact performance in addition to more complex cognitive human responses, evolving human-machine relationships and next generation AI.

**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES9903 - Narrative and Sensemaking in Immersive Environments","description":"

Story and narrative have been a fundamental part of how we communicate as humans since time immemorial. Advances in technology are today forging new ways of composing and developing narrative experiences. Understanding the changes required for narrative and story composition within immersive and virtual systems will be essential for the communication and future design of compelling systems and experiences.


Focusing on narrative design rather than storytelling, this course examines a spectrum of narrative modalities from visual and cinematic to aural and performative, and draws on contemporary industry examples in simulation, gaming, 360 cinema, virtual reality and installation. You will re-examine story composition in the light of multimodal sensemaking and embodied cognition. You will understand how agency, interactivity, situational awareness and navigation reel in an experiential dimension that extends beyond linear storytelling to the design of narrative in immersive environments. You will also analyse how composition and multimodality impact notions of fidelity, credibility, and empathy.


**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

Advances in technology are today forging new ways of composing and developing narrative experiences. Focusing on narrative design rather than storytelling, this course examines a spectrum of narrative modalities from visual and cinematic to aural and performative, and draws on contemporary industry examples in simulation, gaming, 360 cinema, virtual reality and installation. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES9904 - Models, Systems and Solution Design","description":"

Models form the basis for how we represent the world and design solutions. While they are used differently across domains to analyse, test hypotheses, inform decisions and make predictions, model and systems thinking offers an important perspective to help us understand and shape our environment. 


Answering the question ‘what is a model?’, this course will give you a holistic perspective of models and systems examining how, why and when it is appropriate to model. In particular you will consider how models can be used to help problem-solve and design solutions in industrial and creative contexts. Different modelling and systems paradigms will also be examined with a specific focus on their application in visualisation, simulation and immersive design.


You will evaluate case studies across a diverse range of industries to better understand conceptual questions arising from discrete modelling approaches and undertake practical exercises to test the utility of model and systems thinking in designing solution spaces. Particular emphasis will be given to how we can interpret and evaluate modelling frameworks in order to apprehend any underlying assumptions and biases.


**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

contentlets.description:
Models form the basis for how we represent the world and design solutions. While they are used differently across domains to analyse, test hypotheses, inform decisions and make predictions, model and systems thinking offers an important perspective to help us understand and shape our environment. 

Answering the question ‘what is a model?’, this course will give you a holistic perspective of models and systems examining how, why and when it is appropriate to model. In particular you will consider how models can be used to help problem-solve and design solutions in industrial and creative contexts. Different modelling and systems paradigms will also be examined with a specific focus on their application in visualisation, simulation and immersive design.

You will evaluate case studies across a diverse range of industries to better understand conceptual questions arising from discrete modelling approaches and undertake practical exercises to test the utility of model and systems thinking in designing solution spaces. Particular emphasis will be given to how we can interpret and evaluate modelling frameworks in order to apprehend any underlying assumptions and biases.

**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES9905 - Immersive Design, Complexity and Wicked Problems","description":"

Visualisation, simulation, and immersive design offer new ways of engaging with the complex problems and challenges facing todays society. This course builds on your acquired knowledge across the program and uses constructive design and design thinking processes to analyse ‘wicked’ problems and consider how they might be addressed using visualisation, simulation and immersive design.


You will be asked to embrace complexity, ambiguity and the interdependencies of diverse stakeholder and discipline world views in relation to real-world challenges. You will learn how to work collaboratively to examine conflicting value systems and to experiment with novel approaches to problem solving using design processes, rapid prototyping and simulation.


**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.

contentlets.keywords: domain design,visualisation,simulation,immersive design,design thinking,complexity,wicked problems,rapid prototyping,experimentation,constructive design,future forecasting
contentlets.description:
Visualisation, simulation, and immersive design offer new ways of engaging with the complex problems and challenges facing todays society. This course builds on your acquired knowledge across the program and uses constructive design and design thinking processes to analyse ‘wicked’ problems and consider how they might be addressed using visualisation, simulation and immersive design.

You will be asked to embrace complexity, ambiguity and the interdependencies of diverse stakeholder and discipline world views in relation to real-world challenges. You will learn how to work collaboratively to examine conflicting value systems and to experiment with novel approaches to problem solving using design processes, rapid prototyping and simulation.

**This low residency course has been designed to accommodate busy professionals. Students attend two intensive face to face meetups per year on campus or at our industry partner facilities. Students will also have full access to all campus facilities throughout each term. Students may incur additional travel and accommodation costs.
contentlets.title: Immersive Design, Complexity and Wicked Problems

Simulation and immersive environments are enabling a range of experiential and practice-based learning approaches, propelling the development of a new learning science. This course will help you understand how the properties of immersive environments impact learning and instructional strategies. You will analyse why, how and when to incorporate immersive learning modalities together with how to design,  implement and evaluate learning programs for these contexts.

As immersive practices and technologies become embedded in our workplace environments, business leaders and managers are required to make critical decisions regarding their design, acquisition and operation. Management of the technology life cycle will impact the successful deployment of immersive technologies in any enterprise.


In this course you will learn how to make the business case for the effective use and procurement of an immersive system. This includes undertaking a needs analysis, assessing relative benefits, value and scalability of immersive systems and simulation environments.

contentlets.description:
As immersive practices and technologies become embedded in our workplace environments, business leaders and managers are required to make critical decisions regarding their design, acquisition and operation. Management of the technology life cycle will impact the successful deployment of immersive technologies in any enterprise.

In this course you will learn how to make the business case for the effective use and procurement of an immersive system. This includes undertaking a needs analysis, assessing relative benefits, value and scalability of immersive systems and simulation environments.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"DDES9920","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DDES9920 - Information Architecture for Immersive Aesthetics","description":"

This course examines the principles of information architecture design as they apply to the context content and users of immersive visualisations and simulations. You will learn about systems for data classification and metadata labelling, search methodologies and user navigation, and how these may be translated into interactive systems for embodied environments. The course will help you understand how to move beyond simple technical schemas for data organisation, to consider how the physical and social spaces in which these data are encountered affect the formation of knowledge in users. In doing so, your will combine human-centred design considerations with artificial intelligence-assisted data management practices, and explore new methods for interpreting and visualising information for applications in immersive media.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a63567dbdb613c50be4672f5f396191d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Designing information architectures for immersive environments","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Following on from assessment 2, design an immersive environment and user interface for delivery on a head mounted virtual reality system that allows the user to interrogate the dataset through embodied methodologies. Present your design in a portfolio format using a combination of wireframe diagrams, text and other visual means to theorise your methodology.

Feedback to be given individually via Turnitin and holistically on the course Moodle

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a23567dbdb613c50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa3567dbdb613c50be4672f5f396191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e3567dbdb613c50be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Information architecture analysis and critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Taking into account two learning scenarios experienced in the face to face sessions – T-Visionarium in the Advanced Visualisation and Interaction Environment, and Oculus Medium on Oculus Rift S – as well as required readings and your own research, analyse the organisational systems used to order and interact with data in each use case. Analyse how the user experience differs in each physical/virtual context, and how the information architectures are designed to engage embodied experience.

Feedback to be given individually via Turnitin and holistically on the course Moodle

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aa3567dbdb613c50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a63567dbdb613c50be4672f5f3961924","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data classification and metadata definition","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Examining datasets of 2D images and 3D data and drawing from your experience, construct a database classification schema that will allow for deep interrogation of the maximal variables from the content metadata. Informed by course readings, search methodology for interrogating the dataset. (Written report and online database)

Feedback to be given individually via Turnitin and holistically during class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa3567dbdb613c50be4672f5f396191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ae3567dbdb613c50be4672f5f3961926","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DDES9920.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
